headline.print_headline: Broken Trust Takes Time To Mend
headline.seo: Broken Trust Takes Time to Mend - Economic View
headline.main: Broken Trust Takes Time to Mend

docs.snippet: Too much debate has focused on textbook remedies to the nation’s economic troubles, and not enough on how Americans have lost faith in political solutions to problems....
docs.abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View column contends too much debate has focused on textbook remedies to the nation’s economic troubles, and not enough on Americans' loss of trust and faith in political solutions to problems; holds it is not an easy problem to fix, but the place to start is by recognizing it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Too much debate has focused on textbook remedies to the nation’s economic troubles, and not enough on how Americans have lost faith in political solutions to problems.

headline.print_headline: European Leaders to Present Plan to Quickly Quell the Crisis
headline.seo: European Leaders Present Plan to Quell Euro Zone Crisis
headline.main: European Leaders to Present Plan to Quell the Crisis Quickly

docs.snippet: The plan will include measures to prevent bank runs and push for the repeal of regulations that hinder competition, keep young people out of the work force or make it difficult to start businesses....
docs.abstract: Mario Draghi, the head of the European Central Bank, and other euro zone leaders are working on a grand vision for the euro zone meant to reassure investors and allies that flaws in the currency union will be addressed quickly; plan will include measures to prevent bank runs and reduce what has become a vicious cycle of government debt.

byline.contributor: James Kanter and Paul Geitner contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: The plan will include measures to prevent bank runs and push for the repeal of regulations that hinder competition, keep young people out of the work force or make it difficult to start businesses.

headline.print_headline: When All Looks Bleak, Maybe It’s Time to Invest
headline.seo: Why European Stocks May Be Ripe for Long-Term Gains
headline.main: A Contrarian Case for Investing in Europe

docs.snippet: All of Europe’s bad news may be adding up to some long-term opportunities for stock investors, one asset manager says. But, he adds, it doesn’t look like a place for quick profits....
docs.abstract: Jeff Sommer Strategies column cites Litman Gregory Asset Management investment manager Jeremy DeGroot, who believes the European financial crisis may be offering some long-term opportunities for stock investors; warns, however, that he does not think it looks like a place for quick profits.
docs.lead_paragraph: All of Europe’s bad news may be adding up to some long-term opportunities for stock investors, one asset manager says. But, he adds, it doesn’t look like a place for quick profits.

headline.print_headline: In Greek Vote, Fears Nobody Can Truly Win
headline.seo: In Greece, Fears That Voting Won’t Resolve Turmoil
headline.main: As Greeks Head to Polls Again, a Fear That No One Will Win

docs.snippet: Voters will cast ballots for the second time in two months, worried that any government they elect will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens Greece’s future....
docs.abstract: Greek voters prepare to head to the polls for the second time in two months, attended by a sense of dread that any government that comes to power will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens the country’s future; victorious party will face an uphill battle to inject confidence into a paralyzed economy that depends heavily on the continued infusion of money by the European Central Bank.

byline.original: By RACHEL DONADIO and STEVEN ERLANGER
byline.contributor: Rachel Donadio reported from Athens, and Steven Erlanger from Paris. Jack Ewing contributed reporting from Frankfurt.

docs.lead_paragraph: Voters will cast ballots for the second time in two months, worried that any government they elect will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens Greece’s future.

headline.print_headline: The Day When Europe Holds Its Breath
headline.seo: Euro May Have a Painful Path, Whatever Greece Decides
headline.main: Whatever Greek Voters Decide, the Euro Looks Likely to Suffer

docs.snippet: Greek voters are charting the immediate course of their nation’s role in the euro zone, but the currency’s problems look to be longer-lasting....
docs.abstract: Greek voters are charting the immediate course of their nation’s role in the euro zone, but the euro's problems look to be longer-lasting; currency has weakened steadily as Europe's economic crisis has worsened, recently trading near a two-year low at $1.26.
docs.lead_paragraph: Greek voters are charting the immediate course of their nation’s role in the euro zone, but the currency’s problems look to be longer-lasting.

headline.print_headline: One Crowd Rumbles; the Other Slumbers
headline.seo: Oklahoma City Crowd Rumbles; Miami’s Slumbers
headline.main: One Crowd Rumbles; the Other Slumbers

docs.snippet: The Thunder’s fans in Oklahoma City are clearly leading the Heat’s followers in Miami in the battle of decibel levels....
docs.abstract: Essay; Oklahoma City Thunder's home fans are clearly winning the battle of decibel levels against Miami Heat's fans in Miami.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Thunder’s fans in Oklahoma City are clearly leading the Heat’s followers in Miami in the battle of decibel levels.

headline.print_headline: Caution, Please: The Boss’s Office Is a No-Spin Zone
headline.seo: Shawn Wilson of Usher’s New Look Foundation, on Leadership
headline.main: Caution, Please: The Boss’s Office Is a No-Spin Zone

docs.snippet: Shawn H. Wilson, president of Usher’s New Look Foundation, says that making excuses or spinning the truth is harmful to any organization’s culture....
docs.abstract: Adam Bryant Corner Office column features Usher's New Look Foundation president Shawn H Wilson discussing his management technique.
docs.lead_paragraph: Shawn H. Wilson, president of Usher’s New Look Foundation, says that making excuses or spinning the truth is harmful to any organization’s culture.

headline.print_headline: In Moscow, Iran to Face Critical Choice in the Latest Round of Nuclear Talks
headline.seo: Iran Faces Critical Choice in New Round of Nuclear Talks
headline.main: In Moscow, Iran to Face Critical Choice in the Latest Round of Nuclear Talks

docs.snippet: Less than two weeks after its diplomats meet on Monday with those of six major powers in Moscow, Iran faces a potentially crippling oil embargo and banking sanctions....
docs.abstract: Iran faces the imposition of a potentially crippling European oil embargo and American banking sanctions, less than two weeks after its diplomats meet with those of the United States and five other major powers in Moscow; it is the first of these sessions to be held in one of the negotiating countries, and it comes at a time when Russia, facing international opprobrium because of its ties to the brutal government in Syria, could use a diplomatic victory.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and ELLEN BARRY
byline.contributor: Mark Landler reported from Washington, and Ellen Barry from Moscow. Thomas Erdbrink contributed reporting from Tehran.

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after its diplomats meet on Monday with those of six major powers in Moscow, Iran faces a potentially crippling oil embargo and banking sanctions.

headline.print_headline: 2 Car Bombs Target Shiites In Baghdad
headline.seo: Shiite Pilgrims Targeted in Car Bombings
headline.main: 2 Car Bombs Target Shiites in Baghdad

docs.snippet: Two car bombings in the Baghdad area killed more than 30 Shiite pilgrims at the end of the celebration....
docs.abstract: Security clampdown aimed at protecting Shiite pilgrims fails to prevent a new round of carnage as two car bombings in Baghdad kill more than 30 at the end of a weeklong celebration; attacks represent an embarrassment to the Iraqi army and police, and raise questions about the ability of Iraq’s security forces to protect the population.

byline.original: By DURAID ADNAN and TIM ARANGO

docs.lead_paragraph: Two car bombings in the Baghdad area killed more than 30 Shiite pilgrims at the end of the celebration.

docs.snippet: A reader responds to a recent article about the Federal Reserve’s role in helping to fix the nation’s economic problems....
docs.lead_paragraph: A reader responds to a recent article about the Federal Reserve’s role in helping to fix the nation’s economic problems.
